title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and his mate were working together with some end in view, for the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: she-dog merely galloped steadily at the lidi's right about op-posite
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: his rump.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I had seen jaloks hunting in packs, and I recalled now what for the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: time I had not thought of--the several that ran ahead and turned the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: quarry back toward the main body.  This was precisely what Raja and his
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: mate were doing--they were turning the lidi back toward me, or at least
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Raja was.  Just why the female was keeping out of it I did not
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: understand, unless it was that she was not entirely clear in her own
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: mind as to precisely what her mate was attempting.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: At any rate, I was sufficiently convinced to stop where I was and await
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: developments, for I could readily realize two things.  One was that I
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: could never overhaul them before the damage was done if they should
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: pull the lidi down now.  The other thing was that if they did not pull
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: it down for a few minutes it would have completed its circle and
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: returned close to where I stood.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: And this is just what happened.  The lot of them were almost swallowed
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: up in the twilight for a moment.  Then they reappeared again, but this
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: time far to the right and circling back in my general direction.  I
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: waited until I could get some clear idea of the right spot to gain that
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I might intercept the lidi; but even as I waited I saw the beast
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: attempt to turn still more to the right--a move that would have carried
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: him far to my left in a much more circumscribed circle than the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hyaenodons had mapped out for him.  Then I saw the female leap forward
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and head him; and when he would have gone too far to the left, Raja
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: sprang, snapping at his shoulder and held him straight.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Straight for me the two savage beasts were driving their quarry!  It
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: was wonderful.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: It was something else, too, as I realized while the monstrous beast
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: neared me.  It was like standing in the middle of the tracks in front
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of an approaching express-train.  But I didn't dare waver; too much
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: depended upon my meeting that hurtling mass of terrified flesh with a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: well-placed javelin.  So I stood there, waiting to be run down and
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: crushed by those gigantic feet, but determined to drive home my weapon
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: in the broad breast before I fell.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The lidi was only about a hundred yards from me when Raja gave a few
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: barks in a tone that differed materially from his hunting-cry.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Instantly both he and his mate leaped for the long neck of the ruminant.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Neither missed.  Swinging in mid-air, they hung tenaciously, their
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: weight dragging down the creature's head and so retarding its speed
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: that before it had reached me it was almost stopped and devoting all
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: its energies to attempting to scrape off its attackers with its
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: forefeet.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Dian had seen and recognized me, and was trying to extricate herself
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: from the grasp of her captor, who, handicapped by his strong and agile
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: prisoner, was unable to wield his lance effectively upon the two
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: jaloks.  At the same time I was running swiftly toward them.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: When the man discovered me he released his hold upon Dian and sprang to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the ground, ready with his lance to meet me.  My javelin was no match
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: for his longer weapon, which was used more for stabbing than as a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: missile.  Should I miss him at my first cast, as was quite probable,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: since he was prepared for me, I would have to face his formidable lance
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: with nothing more than a stone knife.  The outlook was scarcely
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: entrancing.  Evidently I was soon to be absolutely at his mercy.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Seeing my predicament, he ran toward me to get rid of one antagonist
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: before he had to deal with the other two.  He could not guess, of
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: course, that the two jaloks were hunting with me; but he doubtless
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: thought that after they had finished the lidi they would make after the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: human prey--the beasts are notorious killers, often slaying wantonly.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: But as the Thurian came Raja loosened his hold upon the lidi and dashed
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: for him, with the female close after.  When the man saw them he yelled
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: to me to help him, protesting that we should both be killed if we did
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: not fight together.  But I only laughed at him and ran toward Dian.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Both the fierce beasts were upon the Thurian simu-taneously--he must
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: have died almost before his body tumbled to the ground.  Then the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: female wheeled toward Dian.  I was standing by her side as the thing
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: charged her, my javelin ready to receive her.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: But again Raja was too quick for me.  I imagined he thought she was
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: making for me, for he couldn't have known anything of my relations
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: toward Dian.  At any rate he leaped full upon her back and dragged her
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: down.  There ensued forthwith as terrible a battle as one would wish to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: see if battles were gaged by volume of noise and riotousness of action.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I thought that both the beasts would be torn to shreds.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: When finally the female ceased to struggle and rolled over on her back,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: her forepaws limply folded, I was sure that she was dead.  Raja stood
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: over her, growling, his jaws close to her throat.  Then I saw that
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: neither of them bore a scratch.  The male had simply administered a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: severe drubbing to his mate.  It was his way of teaching her that I was
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: sacred.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: After a moment he moved away and let her rise, when she set about
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: smoothing down her rumpled coat, while he came stalking toward Dian and
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: me.  I had an arm about Dian now.  As Raja came close I caught him by
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the neck and pulled him up to me.  There I stroked him and talked to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: him, bidding Dian  do the same, until I think he pretty well understood
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: that if I was his friend, so was Dian.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: For a long time he was inclined to be shy of her, often baring his
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: teeth at her approach, and it was a much longer time before the female
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: made friends with us. But by careful kindness, by never eating without
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: sharing our meat with them, and by feeding them from our hands, we
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: finally won the confidence of both animals.  However, that was a long
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: time after.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: With the two beasts trotting after us, we returned to where we had left
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Juag.  Here I had the dickens' own time keeping the female from Juag's
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: throat.  Of all the venomous, wicked, cruel-hearted beasts on two
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: worlds, I think a female hyaenodon takes the palm.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: But eventually she tolerated Juag as she had Dian and me, and the five
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of us set out toward the coast, for Juag had just completed his labors
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: on the thag when we arrived.  We ate some of the meat before starting,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and gave the hounds some.  All that we could we carried upon our backs.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: On the way to the canoe we met with no mishaps.  Dian told me that the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: fellow who had stolen her had come upon her from behind while the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: roaring of the thag had drowned all other noises, and that the first
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: she had known he had disarmed her and thrown her to the back of his
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: lidi, which had been lying down close by waiting for him.  By the time
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the thag had ceased bellowing the fellow had got well away upon his
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: swift mount.  By holding one palm over her mouth he had prevented her
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: calling for help.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "I thought," she concluded, "that I should have to use the viper's
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: tooth, after all."
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: We reached the beach at last and unearthed the canoe.  Then we busied
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: ourselves stepping a mast and rigging a small sail--Juag and I, that
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: is--while Dian cut the thag meat into long strips for drying when we
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: should be out in the sunlight once more.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: At last all was done.  We were ready to embark.  I had no difficulty in
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: getting Raja aboard the dugout; but Ranee--as we christened her after I
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: had explained to Dian the meaning of Raja and its feminine
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: equivalent--positively refused for a time to follow her mate aboard.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: In fact, we had to shove off without her.  After a moment, however, she
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: plunged into the water and swam after us.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I let her come alongside, and then Juag and I pulled her in, she
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: snapping and snarling at us as we did so; but, strange to relate, she
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: didn't offer to attack us after we had ensconced her safely in the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: bottom alongside Raja.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The canoe behaved much better under sail than I had hoped--infinitely
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: better than the battle-ship Sari had--and we made good progress almost
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: due west across the gulf, upon the opposite side of which I hoped to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: find the mouth of the river of which Juag had told me.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The islander was much interested and impressed by the sail and its
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: results.  He had not been able to understand exactly what I hoped to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: accomplish with it while we were fitting up the boat; but when he saw
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the clumsy dugout move steadily through the water without paddles, he
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: was as delighted as a child.  We made splendid headway on the trip,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: coming into sight of land at last.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Juag had been terror-stricken when he had learned that I intended
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: crossing the ocean, and when we passed out of sight of land he was in a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: blue funk.  He said that he had never heard of such a thing before in
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: his life, and that always he had understood that those who ventured far
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: from land never returned; for how could they find their way when they
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: could see no land to steer for?
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I tried to explain the compass to him; and though he never really
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: grasped the scientific explanation of it, yet he did learn to steer by
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: it quite as well as I. We passed several islands on the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: journey--islands which Juag told me were entirely unknown to his own
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: island folk.  Indeed, our eyes may have been the first ever to rest
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: upon them.  I should have liked to stop off and explore them, but the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: business of empire would brook no unnecessary delays.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I asked Juag how Hooja expected to reach the mouth of the river which
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: we were in search of if he didn't cross the gulf, and the islander
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: explained that Hooja would undoubtedly follow the coast around.  For
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: some time we sailed up the coast searching for the river, and at last
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: we found it.  So great was it that I thought it must be a mighty gulf
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: until the mass of driftwood that came out upon the first ebb tide
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: convinced me that it was the mouth of a river.  There were the trunks
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of trees uprooted by the undermining of the river banks, giant
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: creepers, flowers, grasses, and now and then the body of some land
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: animal or bird.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I was all excitement to commence our upward journey when there
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: occurred that which I had never before seen within Pellucidar--a really
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: terrific wind-storm.  It blew down the river upon us with a ferocity
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and suddenness that took our breaths away, and before we could get a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: chance to make the shore it became too late.  The best that we could do
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: was to hold the scud-ding craft before the wind and race along in a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: smother of white spume.  Juag was terrified.  If Dian was, she hid it;
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: for was she not the daughter of a once great chief, the sister of a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: king, and the mate of an emperor?
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Raja and Ranee were frightened.  The former crawled close to my side
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and buried his nose against me.  Finally even fierce Ranee was moved to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: seek sympathy from a human being.  She slunk to Dian, pressing close
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: against her and whimpering, while Dian stroked her shaggy neck and
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: talked to her as I talked to Raja.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: There was nothing for us to do but try to keep the canoe right side up
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and straight before the wind.  For what seemed an eternity the tempest
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: neither increased nor abated.  I judged that we must have blown a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hundred miles before the wind and straight out into an unknown sea!
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: As suddenly as the wind rose it died again, and when it died it veered
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: to blow at right angles to its former course in a gentle breeze.  I
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: asked Juag then what our course was, for he had had the compass last.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: It had been on a leather thong about his neck.  When he felt for it,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the expression that came into his eyes told me as plainly as words what
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: had happened--the compass was lost!  The compass was lost!
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: And we were out of sight of land without a single celestial body to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: guide us! Even the pendent world was not visible from our position!
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Our plight seemed hopeless to me, but I dared not let Dian and Juag
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: guess how utterly dismayed I was; though, as I soon discovered, there
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: was nothing to be gained by trying to keep the worst from Juag--he knew
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: it quite as well as I. He had always known, from the legends of his
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: people, the dangers of the open sea beyond the sight of land.  The
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: compass, since he had learned its uses from me, had been all that he
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: had to buoy his hope of eventual salvation from the watery deep.  He
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: had seen how it had guided me across the water to the very coast that I
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: desired to reach, and so he had implicit confidence in it.  Now that it
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: was gone, his confidence had departed, also.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: There seemed but one thing to do; that was to keep on sailing straight
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: before the wind--since we could travel most rapidly along that
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: course--until we sighted land of some description.  If it chanced to be
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the mainland, well and good; if an island--well, we might live upon an
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: island.  We certainly could not live long in this little boat, with
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: only a few strips of dried thag and a few quarts of water left.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Quite suddenly a thought occurred to me.  I was surprised that it had
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: not come before as a solution to our problem.  I turned toward Juag.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "You Pellucidarians are endowed with a wonderful instinct," I reminded
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: him, "an instinct that points the way straight to your homes, no matter
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: in what strange land you may find yourself.  Now all we have to do is
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: let Dian guide us toward Amoz, and we shall come in a short time to the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: same coast whence we just were blown."
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: As I spoke I looked at them with a smile of renewed hope; but there was
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: no answering smile in their eyes.  It was Dian who enlightened me.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "We could do all this upon land," she said.  "But upon the water that
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: power is denied us.  I do not know why; but I have always heard that
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: this is true--that only upon the water may a Pellucidarian be lost.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: This is, I think, why we all fear the great ocean so--even those who go
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: upon its surface in canoes.  Juag has told us that they never go beyond
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the sight of land."
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: We had lowered the sail after the blow while we were discussing the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: best course to pursue.  Our little craft had been drifting idly, rising
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and falling with the great waves that were now diminishing.  Sometimes
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: we were upon the crest--again in the hollow.  As Dian ceased speaking
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: she let her eyes range across the limitless expanse of billowing
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: waters.  We rose to a great height upon the crest of a mighty wave.  As
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: we topped it Dian gave an exclamation and pointed astern.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Boats!" she cried.  "Boats! Many, many boats!"
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Juag and I leaped to our feet; but our little craft had now dropped to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the trough, and we could see nothing but walls of water close upon
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: either hand.  We waited for the next wave to lift us, and when it did
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: we strained our eyes in the direction that Dian had indicated.  Sure
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: enough, scarce half a mile away were several boats, and scattered far
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and wide behind us as far as we could see were many others! We could
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: not make them out in the distance or in the brief glimpse that we
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: caught of them before we were plunged again into the next wave canon;
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: but they were boats.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: And in them must be human beings like ourselves.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: CHAPTER XIII
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: RACING FOR LIFE
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: At last the sea subsided, and we were able to get a better view of the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: armada of small boats in our wake.  There must have been two hundred of
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: them.  Juag said that he had never seen so many boats before in all his
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: life.  Where had they come from? Juag was first to hazard a guess.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Hooja," he said, "was building many boats to carry his warriors to the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: great river and up it toward Sari.  He was building them with almost
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: all his warriors and many slaves upon the Island of Trees.  No one else
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: in all the history of Pellucidar has ever built so many boats as they
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: told me Hooja was building.  These must be Hooja's boats."
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "And they were blown out to sea by the great storm just as we were,"
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: suggested Dian.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "There can be no better explanation of them," I agreed.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "What shall we do?" asked Juag.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Suppose we make sure that they are really Hooja's people," suggested
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Dian.  "It may be that they are not, and that if we run away from them
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: before we learn definitely who they are, we shall be running away from
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: a chance to live and find the mainland.  They may be a people of whom
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: we have never even heard, and if so we can ask them to help us--if they
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: know the way to the mainland."
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Which they will not,' interposed Juag.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Well," I said, "it can't make our predicament any more trying to wait
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: until we find out who they are.  They are heading for us now.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Evidently they have spied our sail, and guess that we do not belong to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: their fleet."
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "They probably want to ask the way to the mainland themselves," said
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Juag, who was nothing if not a pessimist.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "If they want to catch us, they can do it if they can paddle faster
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: than we can sail," I said.  "If we let them come close enough to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: discover their identity, and can then sail faster than they can paddle,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: we can get away from them anyway, so we might as well wait."
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: And wait we did.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The sea calmed rapidly, so that by the time the foremost canoe had come
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: within five hundred yards of us we could see them all plainly.  Every
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: one was headed for us.  The dugouts, which were of unusual length, were
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: manned by twenty paddlers, ten to a side.  Besides the paddlers there
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: were twenty-five or more warriors in each boat.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: When the leader was a hundred yards from us Dian called our attention
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: to the fact that several of her crew were Sagoths.  That convinced us
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: that the flotilla was indeed Hooja's.  I told Juag to hail them and get
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: what information he could, while I remained in the bottom of our canoe
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: as much out of sight as possible.  Dian lay down at full length in the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: bottom; I did not want them to see and recognize her if they were in
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: truth Hooja's people.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Who are you?" shouted Juag, standing up in the boat and making a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: megaphone of his palms.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: A figure arose in the bow of the leading canoe--a figure that I was
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: sure I recognized even before he spoke.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "I am Hooja!" cried the man, in answer to Juag.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: For some reason he did not recognize his former prisoner and
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: slave--possibly because he had so many of them.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "I come from the Island of Trees," he continued.  "A hundred of my
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: boats were lost in the great storm and all their crews drowned.  Where
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: is the land? What are you, and what strange thing is that which
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: flutters from the little tree in the front of your canoe?"
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: He referred to our sail, flapping idly in the wind.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "We, too, are lost," replied Juag.  "We know not where the land is.  We
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: are going back to look for it now."
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: So saying he commenced to scull the canoe's nose before the wind, while
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I made fast the primitive sheets that held our crude sail.  We thought
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: it time to be going.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: There wasn't much wind at the time, and the heavy, lumbering dugout was
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: slow in getting under way.  I thought it never would gain any momentum.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: And all the while Hooja's canoe was drawing rapidly nearer, propelled
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: by the strong arms of his twenty paddlers.  Of course, their dugout was
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: much larger than ours, and, consequently, infinitely heavier and more
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: cumbersome; nevertheless, it was coming along at quite a clip, and ours
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: was yet but barely moving.  Dian and I remained out of sight as much as
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: possible, for the two craft were now well within bow-shot of one
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: another, and I knew that Hooja had archers.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Hooja called to Juag to stop when he saw that our craft was moving.  He
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: was much interested in the sail, and not a little awed, as I could tell
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: by his shouted remarks and questions.  Raising my head, I saw him
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: plainly.  He would have made an excellent target for one of my guns,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and I had never been sorrier that I had lost them.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: We were now picking up speed a trifle, and he was not gaining upon us
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: so fast as at first.  In consequence, his requests that we stop
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: suddenly changed to commands as he became aware that we were trying to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: escape him.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Come back!" he shouted.  "Come back, or I'll fire!"
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I use the word fire because it more nearly translates into English the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Pellucidarian word trag, which covers the launching of any deadly
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: missile.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: But Juag only seized his paddle more tightly--the paddle that answered
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the purpose of rudder, and commenced to assist the wind by vigorous
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: strokes.  Then Hooja gave the command to some of his archers to fire
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: upon us.  I couldn't lie hidden in the bottom of the boat, leaving Juag
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: alone exposed to the deadly shafts, so I arose and, seizing another
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: paddle, set to work to help him.  Dian joined me, though I did my best
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: to persuade her to remain sheltered; but being a woman, she must have
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: her own way.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The instant that Hooja saw us he recognized us.  The whoop of triumph
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: he raised indicated how certain he was that we were about to fall into
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: his hands.  A shower of arrows fell about us.  Then Hooja caused his
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: men to cease firing--he wanted us alive.  None of the missiles struck
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: us, for Hooja's archers were not nearly the marksmen that are my
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Sarians and Amozites.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: We had now gained sufficient headway to hold our own on about even
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: terms with Hooja's paddlers.  We did not seem to be gaining, though;
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: and neither did they.  How long this nerve-racking experience lasted I
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: cannot guess, though we had pretty nearly finished our meager supply of
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: provisions when the wind picked up a bit and we commenced to draw away.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Not once yet had we sighted land, nor could I understand it, since so
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: many of the seas I had seen before were thickly dotted with islands.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Our plight was anything but pleasant, yet I think that Hooja and his
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: forces were even worse off than we, for they had no food nor water at
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: all.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Far out behind us in a long line that curved upward in the distance, to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: be lost in the haze, strung Hooja's two hundred boats.  But one would
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: have been enough to have taken us could it have come alongside.  We had
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: drawn some fifty yards ahead of Hooja--there had been times when we
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: were scarce ten yards in advance-and were feeling considerably safer
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: from capture.  Hooja's men, working in relays, were commencing to show
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the effects of the strain under which they had been forced to work
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: without food or water, and I think their weakening aided us almost as
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: much as the slight freshening of the wind.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Hooja must have commenced to realize that he was going to lose us, for
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: he again gave orders that we be fired upon.  Volley after volley of
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: arrows struck about us. The distance was so great by this time that
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: most of the arrows fell short, while those that reached us were
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: sufficiently spent to allow us to ward them off with our paddles.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: However, it was a most exciting ordeal.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Hooja stood in the bow of his boat, alternately urging his men to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: greater speed and shouting epithets at me.  But we continued to draw
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: away from him.  At last the wind rose to a fair gale, and we simply
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: raced away from our pursuers as if they were standing still.  Juag was
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: so tickled that he forgot all about his hunger and thirst.  I think
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: that he had never been entirely reconciled to the heathenish invention
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: which I called a sail, and that down in the bottom of his heart he
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: believed that the paddlers would eventually overhaul us; but now he
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: couldn't praise it enough.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: We had a strong gale for a considerable time, and eventually dropped
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Hooja's fleet so far astern that we could no longer discern them.  And
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: then--ah, I shall never forget that moment--Dian sprang to her feet
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: with a cry of "Land!"
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Sure enough, dead ahead, a long, low coast stretched across our bow.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: It was still a long way off, and we couldn't make out whether it was
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: island or mainland; but at least it was land.  If ever shipwrecked
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: mariners were grateful, we were then.  Raja and Ranee were commencing
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: to suffer for lack of food, and I could swear that the latter often
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: cast hungry glances upon us, though I am equally sure that no such
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hideous thoughts ever entered the head of her mate.  We watched them
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: both most closely, however.  Once while stroking Ranee I managed to get
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: a rope around her neck and make her fast to the side of the boat.  Then
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: I felt a bit safer for Dian.  It was pretty close quarters in that
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: little dugout for three human beings and two practically wild,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: man-eating dogs; but we had to make the best of it, since I would not
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: listen to Juag's suggestion that we kill and eat Raja and Ranee.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: We made good time to within a few miles of the shore.  Then the wind
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: died suddenly out.  We were all of us keyed up to such a pitch of
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: anticipation that the blow was doubly hard to bear.  And it was a blow,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: too, since we could not tell in what quarter the wind might rise again;
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: but Juag and I set to work to paddle the remaining distance.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Almost immediately the wind rose again from precisely the opposite
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: direction from which it had formerly blown, so that it was mighty hard
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: work making progress against it.  Next it veered again so that we had
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: to turn and run with it parallel to the coast to keep from being
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: swamped in the trough of the seas.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: And while we were suffering all these disappointments Hooja's fleet
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: appeared in the distance!
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: They evidently had gone far to the left of our course, for they were
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: now almost behind us as we ran parallel to the coast; but we were not
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: much afraid of being overtaken in the wind that was blowing.  The gale
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: kept on increasing, but it was fitful, swooping down upon us in great
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: gusts and then going almost calm for an instant.  It was after one of
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: these momentary calms that the catastrophe occurred.  Our sail hung
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: limp and our momentum decreased when of a sudden a particularly vicious
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: squall caught us.  Before I could cut the sheets the mast had snapped
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: at the thwart in which it was stepped.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: The worst had happened; Juag and I seized paddles and kept the canoe
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: with the wind; but that squall was the parting shot of the gale, which
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: died out immediately after, leaving us free to make for the shore,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: which we lost no time in attempting.  But Hooja had drawn closer in
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: toward shore than we, so it looked as if he might head us off before we
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: could land.  However, we did our best to distance him, Dian taking a
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: paddle with us.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: We were in a fair way to succeed when there appeared, pouring from
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: among the trees beyond the beach, a horde of yelling, painted savages,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: brandishing all sorts of devilish-looking primitive weapons.  So
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: menacing was their attitude that we realized at once the folly of
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: attempting to land among them.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: Hooja was drawing closer to us.  There was no wind.  We could not hope
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: to outpaddle him.  And with our sail gone, no wind would help us,
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: though, as if in derision at our plight, a steady breeze was now
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: blowing.  But we had no intention of sitting idle while our fate
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: overtook us, so we bent to our paddles and, keeping parallel with the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: coast, did our best to pull away from our pursuers.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: It was a grueling experience.  We were weakened by lack of food.  We
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: were suffering the pangs of thirst.  Capture and death were close at
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: hand.  Yet I think that we gave a good account of ourselves in our
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: final effort to escape.  Our boat was so much smaller and lighter than
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: any of Hooja's that the three of us forced it ahead almost as rapidly
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: as his larger craft could go under their twenty paddles.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: As we raced along the coast for one of those seemingly interminable
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: periods that may draw hours into eternities where the labor is
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: soul-searing and there is no way to measure time, I saw what I took for
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: the opening to a bay or the mouth of a great river a short distance
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: ahead of us.  I wished that we might make for it; but with the menace
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: of Hooja close behind and the screaming natives who raced along the
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: shore parallel to us, I dared not attempt it.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: We were not far from shore in that mad flight from death.  Even as I
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: paddled I found opportunity to glance occasionally toward the natives.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: They were white, but hideously painted.  From their gestures and
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: weapons I took them to be a most ferocious race.  I was rather glad
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: that we had not succeeded in landing among them.
title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: each other's way, and were enabled to fire our cannon and our small
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: was.  I am free to confess that I marveled at the excellent
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

text: ship.

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: as fast as they came we mowed them down.  It was little else than
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: them their lives if they would do so.  At last there were but ten
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: boatloads left.  These turned in flight.  They thought they could

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: us.  Then we set out after them.  There was a nice little breeze

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

title: Pellucidar

title: Pellucidar

text: dugout.
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: "Throw down your arms and come aboard us," I cried, "and you shall not

text: of Pellucidar again!"

author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: would kill you the moment you landed."

title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: charge surrendered.  The Sagoths threw down their weapons, and we took
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: them aboard the ship next in line behind the Amoz.  First Ja had to
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: impress upon the captain and crew of the ship that the prisoners were
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: not to be abused or killed.  After that the remaining dugouts paddled
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: up and surrendered.  We distributed them among the entire fleet lest
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: there be too many upon any one vessel.  Thus ended the first real naval
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: engagement that the Pellucidarian seas had ever witnessed--though Perry
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice

text: still insists that the action in which the Sari took part was a battle
title: Pellucidar
author: Burroughs, Edgar Rice
